Chapter 2.35: The Chrysobull


March 27, 1435
Palace of Blachernae, Constantinople



The first pale light of dawn crept over the rooftops of Constantinople, turning the eastern horizon from black to grey to palest gold. From the private courtyard of Juan's quarters in the Blachernae, the city's minarets and church domes alike caught that light—a forest of spires silhouetted against the brightening sky, some crowned with crosses, some with crescents.


Isaac de Baeza set down his quill and flexed his fingers. The parchment before them bore the fruits of a sleepless night: the Chrysobull of the United Treasury, written in both Latin and Greek, the parallel columns of text precise and elegant despite the haste of their creation.


"It is done, Majesty." Isaac's voice carried the hoarseness of exhaustion, but his dark eyes remained sharp. "Six articles. Clean language. Nothing the Emperor can misunderstand, nothing he can claim was hidden from him." He tapped the succession clause—Article V. "And this is the heart of it. When the Palaiologos line fails—when, not if—the Defensor assumes not merely the treasury but 'all obligations, ceremonies, institutions, and dignities.' Everything except the title itself."


A servant had brought warm water and fresh bread sometime in the small hours. The bread lay untouched. Isaac had drunk his fill; Juan had not.


Beyond the courtyard walls, the city was stirring. The faint calls of fishermen carried up from the Golden Horn. Somewhere a rooster crowed, answered by another, then another—a chain of waking sounds spreading through the Latin and Greek quarters alike.


"The Emperor will have risen for morning prayers by now," Isaac continued, rolling the parchment carefully. "Patriarch Joseph keeps him to the ancient schedule. Matins at dawn, then a light meal, then audiences begin. If you wish to catch him before others fill his ears..." He let the implication hang.


The document itself was beautiful—Isaac had seen to that. Byzantine conventions required such things: the precise gold-leaf borders that would be added by imperial scribes, the spaces for the Emperor's crimson signature and the great seal of the Palaiologoi. Form mattered in Constantinople. It always had.


But the substance...


Twenty-two thousand florins a year. The income of a prosperous kingdom. And in exchange, the Emperor would sign away control of every hyperper that flowed through his treasury, every talent of silver, every customs duty, every tax. He would retain his purple robes, his ceremonies, his titles. He would not retain his power.


Isaac had called it the best bargain Juan had ever made. But bargains required two parties willing to agree.


The sky continued to brighten. Somewhere in the palace, in the imperial apartments that had housed Caesars for a thousand years, John VIII Palaiologos was waking to another day as Emperor of the Romans.


And soon, he would have to decide what that title was truly worth.

Mosaic saints watched from walls darkened by centuries of incense smoke. The wait was brief. Whatever John VIII Palaiologos had become, he was not a man who avoided difficult conversations.



The Emperor's private breakfast chamber was modest by imperial standards—a small room overlooking a garden gone wild with neglect, its fountain dry, its paths overgrown. John sat at a simple table, a plate of olives and bread before him, a cup of watered wine untouched. He wore no purple this morning, only a plain robe of dark blue wool. He looked tired. He always looked tired.


"Defensor." The Emperor gestured to a chair across from him. "You bring documents at dawn. This is either very good news or very bad."


Juan sat. He placed the parchment on the table between them but did not unroll it.


"Neither, Majesty. Or perhaps both. It depends on how you see what I am about to propose."


John's dark eyes—Byzantine eyes, the eyes of emperors stretching back to Constantine the Great—studied Juan's face. "You have given me soldiers, gold, settlers, and a ten-year peace with the Sultan. "You are many things, Juan of Castile. I do not think you are a saint."


"I am not."


"Then ask. Whatever it is, ask. I would rather know than wonder."


Juan unrolled the parchment, turning it so the Emperor could read the Greek column. He said nothing while John's eyes moved down the text, watching the older man's face as understanding slowly dawned.


The Emperor read in silence. His expression did not change—he had been trained from childhood to show nothing—but his hand, resting on the table, slowly closed into a fist.


When he finished, he did not look up immediately. He stared at Article V for a long moment. All obligations, ceremonies, institutions, and dignities.


"You have written my abdication," John VIII said quietly. "In everything but name."


He raised his eyes to meet Juan's. There was no anger there. No outrage. Only a terrible, weary clarity—the look of a man who had always known this moment would come, and had hoped only that it would not come in his lifetime.


"Twenty-two thousand florins a year. A comfortable retirement for an emperor of nothing." His voice was flat. "My ancestors ruled from the Pillars of Hercules to the Euphrates. And I am to become your pensioner."


The garden outside was silent. Even the birds seemed to have stopped singing.


"Tell me, Defensor." The title carried a new weight now—ironic, perhaps bitter. "Why should I sign this? Why should I not simply take what you have given, wait for you to sail home, and rule my city as my fathers did?"
